questions.text: Five weeks after delivery, a 1350-g (3-lb 0-oz) male newborn has respiratory distress. He was born at 26 weeks' gestation. He required intubation and mechanical ventilation for 1 month following delivery and has been on noninvasive pressure ventilation for 5 days. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 148/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 60/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 40% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions. Scattered crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tracheomalacia may be present in this infant as a result of prolonged intubation and the development of chronic lung disease. While tracheomalacia can also cause respiratory distress, this patient's presentation is not consistent with the wheezing and stridor typically seen with tracheomalacia. Moreover, the reported oxygen saturation of 91% on 40% oxygen represents significant hypoxemia; it would be unusual for tracheomalacia alone to cause this degree of desaturation. Also, tracheomalacia would not explain this patient's x-ray findings.

B) INCORRECT:

This neonate has several risk factors for the development of pneumonia, including prematurity and prolonged intubation. Although aspects of his clinical presentation are consistent with pneumonia (e.g., hypoxemia and tachypnea), key cardinal features are absent, such as fever, cough, or typical x-ray findings of a lobar process. This patient's x-ray findings are more indicative of a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity is a complication of prolonged mechanical ventilation in premature infants. This neonate demonstrates the classic presentation of BPD, which includes persistent tachypnea, labored breathing (intercostal and subcostal retractions), the need for oxygen supplementation to maintain a peripheral saturation ≥ 90% at ≥ 28 days of postnatal age, and diffuse granular densities with basal atelectasis on x-ray. Later in the disease course, interspersed cystic areas and diffuse hyperinflation of the lung can develop. Treatment of BPD primarily focuses on limiting oxygen toxicity and preventing complications (specifically pneumothorax, cardiovascular collapse, and neonatal sepsis).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view) of an intubated newborn with bronchopulmonary dysplasia

Ill-defined reticular markings (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and small rounded lucent areas (examples indicated by green arrowheads) are diffusely present throughout both lungs.

An endotracheal tube (green overlay), nasogastric tube (red overlay), and central venous catheter (yellow overlay) are properly positioned. Rotation of the patient to the left has resulted in an appearance of elongation of the left ribs compared to the right ribs and leftward positioning of the cardiomediastinal silhouette.

D) INCORRECT:

In neonates, strong risk factors for the development of interstitial emphysema are prematurity and prolonged intubation, both of which are present here. The clinical presentation is extremely variable and can range from asymptomatic to severe hypoxemia secondary to compression of vital cardiopulmonary structures. In these severe cases, complications such as pneumomediastinum or pneumothorax are sometimes present. Typical x-ray findings include cystic radiolucencies in the interstitium radiating from the lung hila rather than the diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis seen in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) is classically seen in pediatric patients with a history of severe lung infection, especially adenovirus pneumonia. BO is a possible cause of respiratory distress in an infant and x-ray findings are often nonspecific. However, the presentation of BO is most often vague and consists of coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Although the pathophysiology is not entirely understood, symptoms commonly develop over years. BO would be unlikely in this 5-week-old patient with no history of significant infection.
questions.hint: This premature infant was exposed to prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: Twenty minutes after delivery by lower segment cesarean section at 38 weeks' gestation, a 4630-g (10-lb 3-oz) male newborn has respiratory distress. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother, a 23-year-old primigravid woman, smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily during her pregnancy. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. The newborn's temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 155/min; and respirations are 72/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Grunting and mild intercostal and subcostal retractions are present. Diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. An x-ray of the chest shows increased lung volume and fluid within the interlobar fissures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

TTN is a benign condition that can occur up to 2 hours after delivery and usually resolves without complications within 72 hours. Therapy consists of supportive care, including providing supplemental oxygen by hood or nasal cannula (with a goal O2 saturation of ≥ 90 %), maintaining a neutral thermal environment, and providing adequate nutrition. TTN rarely requires a higher level of care; however, nasal continuous positive airway pressure should be initiated if the required inspired O2 concentration is > 40 %, or if the newborn stays tachypneic with increased work of breathing despite other supplemental O2 delivery methods. Finally, other causes of respiratory distress (e.g., pneumonia, neonatal sepsis, congenital heart condition) should be excluded.

TTN is caused by delayed resorption of fetal lung fluid and most commonly occurs after cesarean delivery, which does not allow fluid to be squeezed out of the neonate's lungs (compared to vaginal delivery).

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy would be the therapy of choice for suspected neonatal sepsis. Although this patient is in respiratory distress, he lacks signs of infection (e.g., temperature instability, tachycardia, lethargy). Additionally, he has no neonatal risk factors (e.g., intrapartum fetal tachycardia, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, Apgar score ≤ 6) or maternal risk factors (e.g., Group B Streptococcus colonization, maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes) for sepsis. However, given his clinical presentation, a CBC with differential should be obtained to rule out an infection. If tachypnea is persistent or if a complete blood count and differential suggests an infection, then blood cultures should be obtained and empiric antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin and gentamicin) should be initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) should be initiated when neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is suspected. NRDS typically manifests with tachypnea, nasal flaring, moderate to severe retractions, and expiratory grunting. However, this condition usually affects premature infants who have insufficient surfactant levels. Also, chest x-ray in infants with NRDS would show bilateral ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms and decreased lung volumes; not fluid in the lung fissures. Additionally, breath sounds would be diminished on auscultation. While nasal CPAP may eventually be used, it is not the first step in the management of TTN.

D) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is used to close a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in neonates. Large PDAs can cause signs of heart failure, including respiratory distress. However, it would be unlikely for this patient to present with respiratory distress due to heart failure within minutes after birth from a PDA. Furthermore, there is no evidence of a murmur to suggest a PDA.

E) INCORRECT:

Surfactant therapy is effective in reducing morbidity and mortality in preterm infants with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) who fail an initial nasal continuous positive airway pressure trial. Although this patient is in respiratory distress, he is full-term and should have adequate surfactant levels. Furthermore, his chest x-ray is not consistent with NRDS, as bilateral ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms and decreased lung volumes would be expected. Additionally, breath sounds would be diminished on auscultation in NRDS.

F) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation would be indicated for neonates with persistent respiratory distress despite non-invasive ventilatory means (e.g., nasal cannula followed by continuous positive airway pressure). TTN rarely requires endotracheal intubation.

G) INCORRECT:

Nitric oxide (NO) therapy would be indicated in patients with persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) who do not respond to supportive measures. Inhaled NO reduces the ratio of pulmonary to systemic vascular resistance to improve blood oxygenation. Although PPHN can manifest with respiratory distress, the chest x-ray is typically normal.
questions.hint: Tachypnea, increased breathing effort, and diffuse crackles on auscultation in a full-term, macrosomic newborn born via cesarean delivery indicate transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN). Gestational diabetes mellitus is a known risk factor for this condition.

questions.text: Three hours after delivery, a 1800-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old primigravid woman. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 69/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows nasal flaring and expiratory grunting. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Misplacement of aorta and pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) due to surfactant deficiency. NRDS is most common in premature infants because adequate surfactant concentration is not reached until 34 weeks' gestation. Without sufficient surfactant, increased surface tension of alveolar air sacs leads to their collapse, resulting in atelectasis, and decreased lung compliance. NRDS manifests up to 72 hours after birth with signs and symptoms of acute respiratory distress such as tachypnea (i.e., respiratory rate > 60/min), cyanosis, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds. Treatment primarily consists of noninvasive ventilation via nasal continuous positive airway pressure. If ventilation alone is unsuccessful, artificial surfactant can be administered endotracheally (see “Overview of NDRDS and its differential diagnoses” table).

As the lungs mature, lecithin levels, the major component of surfactant, increases. Therefore, amniotic fluid lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio can be used to assess for lung maturity, since sphingomyelin remains relatively constant. A ratio > 2 indicates adequate levels of surfactant.
Image Description:

Surfactant reduces alveolar surface tension. In surfactant deficiency, increased surface tension results in increased alveolar collapse during expiration and decreased alveolar expansion during inspiration.

B) INCORRECT:

Persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) can also lead to respiratory distress. With high pulmonary pressures, right-to-left shunting through fetal circulatory pathways (e.g., ductus arteriosus, foramen ovale) results in deoxygenated blood entering systemic circulation, causing hypoxia and cyanosis. Since the lung parenchyma is normal in PPHN, the chest x-ray would show clear lungs with decreased pulmonary vasculature due to shunting.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased lung vascular permeability (secondary to damage to the alveolar-capillary interface) can cause acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in adults. This newborn's respiratory distress is due to another underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have impaired ciliary function and thus impaired lung mucus clearance, which can result also in respiratory distress. However, primary ciliary dyskinesia is an extremely rare condition that has no association with premature delivery. Another cause of this patient's respiratory distress is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Delayed reabsorption of lung fluid can result in transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN), which also causes respiratory distress. However, TTN occurs most commonly in newborns > 35 weeks' gestation who are delivered by cesarean section without labor. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show hyperinflation, perihilar streaking, and fluid in the fissures.

F) INCORRECT:

Transposition of the great vessels (TGV) can manifest with respiratory distress (due to impaired oxygenation of the blood), but there would likely be a single loud S2 and a systolic heart murmur from an accompanying VSD on auscultation. Additionally, a chest x-ray would show normal lung parenchyma, increased pulmonary vascular markings, and an “egg on a string” appearance of the heart.

G) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia due to group B streptococcus (GBS) can cause respiratory distress. Moreover, a chest x-ray, although results vary, could show bilateral alveolar densities that can be similar in appearance to what this patient has. However, this diagnosis is less likely especially because of this patient's prematurity and the lack of any predisposing maternal factors for GBS pneumonia (e.g., GBS genitourinary or gastrointestinal colonization, fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged/premature rupture of membranes).

H) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of meconium during delivery can also lead to respiratory distress. However, meconium aspiration syndrome usually occurs in term or post-term neonates (because meconium usually first develops after 34 weeks' gestation) who have evidence of meconium in the amniotic fluid. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show patchy infiltrates, and hyperinflation secondary to air trapping from sticky meconium.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows diffuse ground-glass opacities and air bronchograms.

questions.text: Two hours after delivery, a 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress. She was born at 32 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was complicated by pregnancy-induced hypertension. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 64/min. Examination shows bluish extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. There are decreased breath sounds bilaterally on auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows reduced lung volume and diffuse reticulogranular densities. Supplemental oxygen is administered by nasal cannula. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nitric oxide therapy would be indicated in patients with persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) who do not respond to supportive measures but has no role in the treatment of NRDS. Although PPHN can manifest with acute respiratory distress, an chest x-ray would show clear lungs with decreased pulmonary vasculature due to shunting rather than reduced lung volume and diffuse reticulogranular densities.

B) INCORRECT:

Antenatal corticosteroid therapy should be given to all pregnant mothers between 23–34 weeks' gestation who are at high risk for preterm delivery within the next week. Steroids help with lung maturation and increase surfactant production to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with preterm delivery. However, corticosteroids are only a preventative measure and have no role in the treatment of NRDS after delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation is appropriate for neonates with NRDS who fail initial therapy but is not the first step because management with intubation is associated with more complications (e.g., bronchopulmonary dysplasia, lung injury).

D) INCORRECT:

Partial exchange transfusion is indicated for neonates with polycythemia who remain symptomatic (e.g., cyanosis, apnea, poor feeding) despite supportive measures (e.g., IV hydration). Most patients with polycythemia are asymptomatic, and this patient has NRDS, which would not respond to partial exchange transfusion.

E) CORRECT:

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) ventilation applying positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is the first step in management of NRDS. Surfactant deficiency in NRDS leads to increased surface tension in the alveolar sacs that results in alveolar collapse, atelectasis, and ventilation-perfusion mismatch. PEEP helps to prevent alveolar collapse by providing pressure at the end of expiration when alveoli are most prone to collapse. After initiation of CPAP, an arterial blood gas analysis should be obtained to assess the effectiveness of respiratory support. If FiO2 > 0.4 or pH < 7.25, endotracheal intubation and surfactant administration are warranted. The younger the gestational age of the neonate, the greater the chance of CPAP failure and poor outcomes.

Because nasal CPAP is a noninvasive procedure, it should be attempted before surfactant therapy, which requires intubation and is associated with more complications (e.g., pulmonary injury, misplacement of the endotracheal tube).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infant

The lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.

In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

F) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin and gentamicin therapy would be appropriate empiric antibiotics if a neonatal infection was suspected. Although Group B Streptococcus (GBS) pneumonia can resemble ARDS on chest x-ray, this patient has no maternal (e.g., GBS genitourinary or gastrointestinal colonization, maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes) or neonatal risk factors (e.g., intrapartum fetal tachycardia, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, Apgar score less than or equal to 6) for infection. Moreover, antibiotics would not be initiated before respiratory support was provided.

G) INCORRECT:

Surfactant administration within 2 hours postpartum has been shown to reduce mortality in neonates with NRDS. However, surfactant therapy requires endotracheal intubation, which is associated with complications such as pulmonary injury and misplacement of the endotracheal tube. Therefore, a less invasive therapy is the preferred initial step in management. Intubation and surfactant administration are warranted if the neonate continues to be in respiratory distress and cannot maintain oxygen saturation despite initial therapy.
questions.hint: Signs of increased breathing effort (tachypnea, subcostal retractions), cyanosis, grunting, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation in a preterm neonate indicate neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). The x-ray with low lung volumes and diffuse reticulogranular (ground-glass) densities confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 1780-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 30 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 64/min, and blood pressure is 61/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows pale extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn can also manifest with respiratory distress shortly after birth. However, this condition most commonly occurs in term neonates delivered by cesarean section, not preterm infants born by vaginal delivery. Furthermore, diffuse crackles rather than decreased breath sounds are typically heard on lung auscultation due to pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is caused by immature respiratory control and is commonly seen in preterm neonates or neonates with very low birth weight. While this patient's prematurity puts him at increased risk of developing AOP, the condition characteristically manifests with episodes of breathing pauses (usually > 20 seconds) that are frequently accompanied by hypoxemia and/or bradycardia. This patient has no evidence of prolonged apnea and his pulmonary findings are suggestive of a lung pathology rather than a lack of respiratory drive.

C) CORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) affects approx. 10% of preterm infants and typically manifests with tachypnea (i.e., respiratory rate > 60/min), low O2 saturation, cyanosis, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, subcostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds. A chest x-ray showing diffuse, ground-glass densities with atelectasis confirms the diagnosis. Treatment of NRDS primarily involves emergent resuscitative measures, including nasal continuous positive airway pressure and stabilizing blood sugar levels and electrolytes.

See “Overview of NRDS and its differential diagnoses” table.
Image Description:

X-ray chest of a premature infant

D) INCORRECT:

Meconium aspiration syndrome can also manifest with respiratory distress. However, this condition most commonly affects term or postterm neonates. Furthermore, there is usually some evidence of meconium in the amniotic fluid.

E) INCORRECT:

Although severe forms of tracheomalacia can also manifest with respiratory distress (especially when the condition is exacerbated by stress and/or respiratory tract infections), this is usually a benign condition that resolves with airway maturation. More pertinently, this newborn lacks expiratory stridor and wheezing, which typically occurs in tracheomalacia due to tracheal collapse.

F) INCORRECT:

Although neonatal pneumonia can also manifest with respiratory distress, this patient lacks other signs of infection (e.g., temperature instability, lethargy). He also has no maternal (e.g., GBS genitourinary or gastrointestinal colonization, fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes, premature rupture of membranes) or neonatal risk factors (e.g., intrapartum fetal tachycardia, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, Apgar score below than or equal to 6) for infection.

G) INCORRECT:

Tracheoesophageal fistula can also manifest with respiratory distress shortly after birth, usually from aspiration of secretions or feeds into the lungs. However, because the upper esophagus ends in a blind pouch, neonates usually exhibit drooling and choking from difficulties in handling their secretions. Inability to pass an orogastric tube would confirm this diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) can manifest with signs of respiratory distress. However, BPD is a chronic lung condition that develops in preterm infants who are exposed to prolonged (>28 days) mechanical ventilation and O2 therapy. Although this patient will be put at risk for BPD if he receives mechanical ventilation, he has no features of this condition at the moment.
questions.hint: This newborn's respiratory distress is most likely due to surfactant deficiency.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 42 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for induction of labor. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her two other children were born after uncomplicated vaginal deliveries at 41 and 42 weeks' gestation, respectively. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (200 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a nontender, soft uterus consistent in size with a 42-weeks' gestation. This patient's child is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with postterm pregnancy are at increased risk for oligohydramnios, not polyhydramnios. Postterm pregnancies can result in placental insufficiency, thereby leading to decreased renal perfusion of the fetus and decreased fetal urine output, and thus oligohydramnios.

B) INCORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is most common in preterm infants, due to insufficient pulmonary surfactant production. The risk for NRDS decreases with advancing gestational age, as the lungs are more likely to be mature and thus produce sufficient surfactant.

C) INCORRECT:

Caudal regression syndrome is associated with maternal diabetes. There is no evidence of insulin resistance in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Postterm pregnancy increases the risk for meconium-stained amniotic fluid. This relationship is likely multifactorial, and due to a combination of fetal gastrointestinal tract maturation, increased fetal stress, and decreased meconium clearance from insufficiency of the aging placenta. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid significantly increases the risk for the development of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS), especially when meconium is found below the vocal cords. Induction of labor between 40–42 weeks' gestation can reduce the risk of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, and thus the development of MAS.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with postterm pregnancy are at increased risk for placental insufficiency, but not placental abruption. Risk factors for placental abruption include previous placental abruption, abdominal trauma, eclampsia, cocaine use, and smoking during pregnancy.
questions.hint: Postterm pregnancy (≥ 42 weeks' gestation) is a strong risk factor for this condition.

questions.text: A male newborn born at 27 weeks' gestation is evaluated for rapid breathing and hypoxia shortly after birth. His mother had no prenatal care. Cardiopulmonary examination shows normal heart sounds, intercostal retractions, and nasal flaring. An x-ray of the chest shows low lung volumes, air bronchograms, and diffuse ground-glass opacities. He is started on nasal continuous positive airway pressure. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Bilateral pleural effusions on lung ultrasound
Corkscrew-shaped organisms on umbilical cord culture
Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral pleural effusions on lung ultrasound are rarely seen in newborns with NRDS. The presence of pleural effusions is a helpful way to distinguish NRDS from early neonatal pneumonia because both processes may show alveolar densities with air bronchograms on chest x-ray. Other causes of pleural effusions in the newborn include congestive heart failure (e.g., due to congenital heart defects), meconium aspiration syndrome, and hydrops fetalis (e.g., hemolytic disease of the newborn).

B) INCORRECT:

Corkscrew-shaped organisms on umbilical cord culture would be suggestive of congenital syphilis due to a Treponema pallidum infection. This newborn's mother had no prenatal care, which increases his risk of congenital infections. However, it is an unlikely cause of his presentation; congenital syphilis is most commonly asymptomatic at birth, or results in stillbirth and/or hydrops fetalis. Early features of congenital syphilis that may develop within the first months are mucopurulent or blood-stained nasal discharge, hepatosplenomegaly, skin lesions (petechiae), and bone abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

Hyaline membranes lining the alveoli on lung biopsy is characteristic of NRDS, which results from surfactant deficiency and is the most common cause of death in premature infants. Surfactant deficiency causes increased alveolar surface tension and a subsequent decrease in lung expansion, leading to alveolar collapse, atelectasis, hypoxemia, and hypercapnia. This patient's chest x-ray shows classic findings of NRDS, including low lung volumes, air bronchograms, and diffuse ground-glass opacities.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

The alveolar walls are lined by eosinophilic hyaline membranes (example indicated by green overlay). The normal basophilic alveolar epithelial lining is absent. Within the interstitium, there is an extensive inflammatory infiltrate, which is visible as numerous basophilic nuclei (large basophilic nuclei: macrophages; multilobed nuclei: neutrophils). There are numerous microthrombi, visible as extracapillary aggregates of RBCs. The capillaries appear congested.

Loss of alveolar epithelium, presence of alveolar hyaline membranes, and interstitial inflammation, edema, and congestion are the typical features of the acute exudative phase of ARDS.

D) INCORRECT:

Meconium-stained fluid on deep suctioning is characteristic of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS). Although respiratory distress and hypoxia are clinical features of MAS, it is unlikely in this premature newborn, as MAS usually develops in term infants, rather than preterm infants. In addition, chest x-ray would show asymmetric, patchy opacities and pleural effusions, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive Coombs test in a neonate is associated with hemolytic disease of the newborn. This condition may manifest with prematurity, hypoxia, and low lung volumes. However, hemolytic disease of the newborn also manifests with signs of hemolysis (e.g., neonatal jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly) and anemia, neither of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, air bronchograms and diffuse ground-glass opacities on chest x-ray are not consistent with hemolytic disease of the newborn.
questions.hint: This premature newborn presents with hypoxia, air bronchograms, and diffuse ground-glass opacities, which is consistent with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS).

questions.text: A 19-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of headache and blurred vision. She has had no prenatal care. She is diagnosed with preeclampsia. Amniocentesis shows a lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio of 0.7. If delivery is induced at this time, the newborn is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with increased pulmonary vascular resistance due to hypoxemia and, therefore, increased rather than decreased right ventricular afterload.

B) INCORRECT:

The diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) depends on the effective alveolar surface area available to participate in gas exchange. In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, surfactant deficiency results in alveolar atelectasis. This decreases effective alveolar surface area and thus decreases rather than increases DLCO. Increased DLCO is expected in conditions such as polycythemia and obesity.

C) CORRECT:

Premature infants are at increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which is characterized by low levels of surfactant (lecithin). As a result, alveolar surface tension increases, causing alveolar atelectasis and decreased lung compliance. This alveolar atelectasis also increases work of breathing and decreases all lung volumes including functional residual capacity. Hypoxemia caused by NRDS would result in increased pulmonary vascular resistance and increased risk of persistent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased lung compliance indicates pliability and low elastic recoil of the airways, which is observed in conditions such as emphysema due to alveolar wall destruction. However, in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, insufficient surfactant production results in alveolar atelectasis, interstitial edema, and hyalinization of small airways. These changes contribute to stiffer lung parenchyma and decreased rather than increased lung compliance.

E) INCORRECT:

Anatomic dead space is the volume of air in airways that do not participate in gas exchange. Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the collapse of alveoli (i.e., atelectasis). The conducting airways, however, are not affected, meaning that the anatomic dead space is unchanged, not increased.
questions.hint: A low lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio in amniotic fluid (< 1.5) indicates fetal lung immaturity, placing the fetus at increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Other amniotic fluid markers of fetal lung immaturity include a low foam stability index (< 0.48) and a low surfactant-albumin ratio.

questions.text: Six hours after birth, a newborn boy is evaluated for tachypnea. He was delivered at 41 weeks' gestation via Caesarian section and the amniotic fluid was meconium-stained. His respiratory rate is 75/min. Physical examination shows increased work of breathing. X-rays of the abdomen and chest show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows elevated pulmonary artery pressure. He is started on an inhaled medication that increases smooth muscle cGMP, and there is immediate improvement in his tachypnea and oxygenation status. Three hours later, the newborn is tachypneic and there is blue-grey discoloration of the lips, fingers, and toes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's cyanosis?

choices.text: Increase in concentration of serum myoglobin
Inhibition of mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum myoglobin can occur as a result of rhabdomyolysis and often manifests with myalgias, weakness, and dark urine (myoglobinuria). Rhabdomyolysis can be of traumatic (e.g., crush injury or direct injury) or nontraumatic cause (e.g., seizures, substance intoxication, or adverse drug reactions of statins and neuroleptics). However, this newborn was delivered by cesarean section and has no risk factors or medications that would suggest rhabdomyolysis or myoglobinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Closure of the ductus arteriosus can cause cyanosis in patients with ductus-dependent anomalies including Tetralogy of Fallot (ToF), pulmonary atresia, critical pulmonary stenosis, and transposition of the great arteries. Since the newborn's chest x-ray was normal and the echocardiography showed only elevated pulmonary artery pressure, a ductus-dependent anomaly is an unlikely cause for cyanosis in this patient. In a patient with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN), which is the most likely diagnosis here, closure of the ductus would likely improve cyanosis, since it is being caused by right-to-left shunting.

C) CORRECT:

Inhaled nitric oxide (NO) is the mainstay treatment for PPHN because of its ability to potently vasodilate the pulmonary vasculature (reducing V/Q mismatch) without decreasing systemic vascular resistance. NO induces smooth muscle relaxation (and subsequent vasodilation) by activating guanylyl cyclase, which increases cGMP synthesis. A side effect of inhaled NO is the oxidation of ferrous iron (Fe2+) to ferric iron (Fe3+) at high levels, resulting in the formation of methemoglobin. Because Fe3+ has a reduced affinity for oxygen binding, methemoglobin is a poor oxygen transporter. Therefore, methemoglobinemia results in poor tissue oxygenation and causes clinical signs of cyanosis. Other side effects of inhaled NO in neonates include platelet dysfunction, pulmonary edema, and the formation of peroxynitrites.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyanide poisoning inhibits mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase, which disrupts the electron transport chain and results in anaerobic metabolism and lactic acidosis. It is typically caused by enclosed-space explosions or fires, or by high-dose sodium nitroprusside treatment. Patients typically present with confusion, headache, nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, flushing, and breath that smells of bitter almonds. Despite its name, cyanide poisoning does not cause cyanosis and is not caused by inhaled nitric oxide.
Image Description:

Uncoupling agents (e.g., salicylic acid, 2,4-dinitrophenol, and thermogenin) act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial inner membrane, resulting in the dissociation of the electron transport chain and the ATP synthase complex.

Respiratory chain inhibitors target specific protein complexes of the electron transport chain. Electron transport chain inhibitors (e.g., rotenone, malonate, antimycin A, and certain toxic substances such as cyanide and aspirin in toxic doses) block ATP synthesis by inhibiting the proton gradient. ATP synthase inhibitors (e.g., oligomycin) block ATP synthesis by inhibiting ATP synthase, the protein complex that catalyzes the synthesis of ATP from ADP and phosphate (Pi).

E) INCORRECT:

Carboxyhemoglobin is formed as a result of carbon monoxide binding to hemoglobin, which results in an allosteric change that shifts the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left. This increases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen and reduces oxygen unloading in the peripheral tissues. Carbon monoxide poisoning is typically caused by exposure to fires, exhaust, or heaters, and manifests with cherry-red skin rather than cyanosis. Carboxyhemoglobinemia does not occur secondary to persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn or administration of nitric oxide.
questions.hint: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure raises suspicion for persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN), a condition in which the pulmonary vascular resistance remains abnormally high after birth. This results in right-to-left shunting of blood via the fetal circulatory pathways, leading to insufficient oxygenation (cyanosis) and tachypnea. Since the pathophysiology of PPHN is aberrantly constricted pulmonary vasculature, a vasodilator in the form of inhaled nitric oxide is given to reduce shunting across the ductus and foramen ovale.

questions.text: A 2350-g (5-lb 3-oz) male newborn delivered at 28 weeks’ gestation develops rapid breathing, grunting, and subcostal retractions 2 hours after delivery. The mother did not receive prenatal care. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 168/min, respirations are 88/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cyanosis and nasal flaring. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse reticulonodular ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An abnormal budding of the ventral foregut leads to dilation of the large bronchi and subsequent formation of bronchogenic cysts. While typically asymptomatic, retention of fluid in the cysts may cause airway compression leading to significant respiratory distress. Chest x-rays in patients with abnormal budding of the foregut would show sharply-defined, fluid-filled densities but not diffuse reticulonodular ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms.

B) CORRECT:

Lamellar bodies, found in type II pneumocytes, are secretory organelles that contain surfactant. Differentiation of type II pneumocytes occurs between weeks 24–34 of gestation, leading to an increase in surfactant production in preparation for lung expansion postpartum. Low amounts of surfactant in premature infants predispose them to NRDS due to alveolar collapse. Artificial surfactant should be administered to this infant. Glucocorticoids promote fetal lung maturity and increase the production of surfactant via stimulation of type II pneumocytes. Glucocorticoids are typically administered at least 48 hours before delivery in patients at risk of preterm birth.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infant

The lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.

In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

A defect in α1 antitrypsin causes α1 antitrypsin deficiency, which results in increased protease activity in the lungs and destruction of the pulmonary architecture with subsequent panacinar emphysema. As a result, patients can present with signs of respiratory insufficiency and decreased breath sounds. However, newborns with severe α1 antitrypsin deficiency would classically show signs of liver disease (prolonged neonatal jaundice due to hepatitis or cirrhosis) before the onset of pulmonary symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity of the bronchial epithelium is the underlying cause of asthma. Allergens trigger a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, causing bronchial-submucosal edemas and smooth muscle contractions, which then lead to dyspnea. Asthma commonly manifests during childhood but it would be an unlikely diagnosis in neonates. Also, a chest x-ray of a patient with severe asthma would show a low, flattened diaphragm and wide intercostal spaces rather than diffuse reticulonodular ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms.

E) INCORRECT:

Meconium aspiration syndrome is associated with signs of severe respiratory distress (e.g., cyanosis, nasal flaring). However, MAS is more common in post-term infants and would classically manifest with green amniotic fluid. In addition, chest x-ray would show asymmetric, patchy opacities and pleural effusions, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.
questions.hint: This premature newborn presents with signs of dyspnea, cyanosis, air bronchograms, and diffuse reticulonodular ground-glass opacities, which is consistent with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS).

questions.text: A 770-g (1-lb 11-oz) female newborn delivered at 28 weeks' gestation develops rapid breathing, grunting, cyanosis, and subcostal retractions shortly after birth. Her mother did not receive any prenatal care. Breath sounds are decreased over both lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse fine, reticular densities bilaterally. Antenatal administration of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this infant's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endogenous epinephrine and other catecholamines are involved in promoting fetal lung maturity in-utero. However, epinephrine administration is not effective for the prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Maternal antenatal administration of betamethasone most likely would have prevented neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) in this patient. Glucocorticoids such as betamethasone and dexamethasone promote fetal lung maturity and increase the production of surfactant via stimulation of type II pneumocyte. Glucocorticoids are typically administered at least 48 hours before delivery in patients at risk of preterm birth, to ensure enough time for effect.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infant

The lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.

In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Endogenous thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) helps increase lung maturity in utero, by increasing T3 and T4 activity and thereby stimulating surfactant release. However, TRH is not used in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome prevention since studies have shown that TRH does not improve outcomes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin is administered primarily to induce labor. While it can slightly increase fetal surfactant levels, oxytocin is not regularly used to promote fetal lung maturity and would not have prevented NRDS in this infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Physiological concentrations of insulin increase glucose uptake by type II pneumocyte and contribute to lung maturity. However, hyperinsulinemia has the opposite effect and delays lung maturity. Consequently, insulin is not used to prevent neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is used therapeutically to close the ductus arteriosus in patients born with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is not indicated in the prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical signs (tachypnea, grunting, subcostal retractions, cyanosis, and decreased breath sounds), imaging findings of diffuse fine, reticular (ground-glass) densities, and history of premature birth without prenatal care make neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: One week after discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit to a regular pediatric ward, a 1450-g (3-lb 1-oz) male infant has respiratory distress and wheezing. After birth, the patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated for 3 weeks because of hypoxia. He required a 60% fraction of inspired oxygen to achieve adequate oxygen saturation. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 59/min, and blood pressure is 65/35 mm Hg. Physical examination shows labored breathing, intercostal retractions, and crackles at both lung bases. There is bluish discoloration around the lips. An x-ray of the chest shows interspersed areas of atelectasis, granular densities, and hyperinflation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) can manifest with features of respiratory distress (e.g., intercostal retractions, tachypnea, cyanosis), nonspecific auscultatory findings including wheezing and crackles, and hyperinflation on chest x-ray due to air-trapping, which are seen here. However, pediatric BO typically occurs following a severe lung infection, especially adenovirus pneumonia, and the clinical features of BO develop over years with a waxing and waning course. BO would be unlikely in this infant with no history of significant infection.

B) CORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity is a complication of prolonged mechanical ventilation in premature infants. This infant has classic features of BPD, which include new-onset respiratory distress, cyanosis due to hypoxemia, and chest x-ray findings such as granular densities and hyperinflation interspersed with areas of atelectasis. Treatment of BPD is primarily focused on limiting oxygen toxicity and preventing complications (e.g., pneumothorax, cardiovascular collapse, neonatal sepsis).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view) of an intubated newborn with bronchopulmonary dysplasia

Ill-defined reticular markings (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and small rounded lucent areas (examples indicated by green arrowheads) are diffusely present throughout both lungs.

An endotracheal tube (green overlay), nasogastric tube (red overlay), and central venous catheter (yellow overlay) are properly positioned. Rotation of the patient to the left has resulted in an appearance of elongation of the left ribs compared to the right ribs and leftward positioning of the cardiomediastinal silhouette.

C) INCORRECT:

Newborns with meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) develop hypoxia immediately after birth and may require mechanical ventilation. Also, a chest x-ray in MAS would show interspersed areas of atelectasis and hyperinflation, which are seen here. However, MAS typically occurs in term and post-term rather than preterm infants; this infant's low body weight suggests that he was born preterm. Moreover, MAS would not explain the new-onset respiratory distress that occurred in this patient one week after discharge from the NICU. In infants with a history of MAS, cyanosis can remain even after the clinical features of MAS resolve if persistent pulmonary hypertension develops. However, chest x-ray is usually normal and crackles would not be expected in such a scenario.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a female neonate

Irregular opacities are present throughout both lungs (examples indicated by green overlay). The lung volumes are large as a result of air trapping.

Dashed lines: diaphragmatic cupola; red line: gastric tube; yellow overlay: central venous catheter

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypoplasia manifests in the neonatal period with features of respiratory distress (e.g., intercostal retractions, tachypnea, cyanosis). However, neither wheezing nor crackles would be expected, and a chest x-ray would show decreased lung volume instead of atelectasis interspersed with hyperinflation. In addition, newborns with this condition typically have other congenital abnormalities (e.g., Potter sequence, rib deformities, anasarca, scaphoid abdomen) as a result of the pathological processes that ultimately lead to pulmonary hypoplasia (e.g., oligohydramnios, thoracic dystrophy, fetal hydrops, diaphragmatic hernia). None of these congenital abnormalities are reported in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

This infant has several risk factors for pneumonia, including prematurity and prolonged intubation. Although aspects of his clinical presentation are consistent with pneumonia (e.g., labored breathing, cyanosis, crackles), other features of neonatal infection such as lethargy, temperature instability, and poor perfusion would be expected. Typical chest x-ray findings of neonatal pneumonia include bilateral alveolar densities with air bronchograms or irregular patchy infiltrates. This patient's x-ray findings are more consistent with a different condition.
questions.hint: This infant's low weight and history of NICU admission suggest that he was born preterm. Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is a common complication of preterm infants, which can require intubation in severe cases. This patient is most likely presenting with a complication of prolonged mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress 10 minutes after delivery. She was born at 42 weeks' gestation via lower segment cesarean section. Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Pregnancy and delivery were complicated by oligohydramnios and green amniotic fluid. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 175/min, and respirations are 65/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Physical examination shows nasal flaring, abdominal breathing, and substernal retractions. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows increased lung volumes and asymmetric, coarse opacities with bilateral effusions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of surfactant via an endotracheal tube
Administration of intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin
Administration of supplemental oxygen via an oxygen hood

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surfactant therapy is routinely administered in patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which can manifest with signs of increased breathing effort (e.g., nasal flaring, substernal retractions, tachypnea) and hypoxia immediately after birth. However, chest x-ray findings would show diffuse, fine, reticulogranular opacities and decreased rather than increased lung volumes. Moreover, the major risk factor for NRDS is premature birth, while this patient was born at 42 weeks' gestation. This patient most likely has MAS, in which surfactant therapy might be indicated in mechanically ventilated patients but is not part of the initial management.

B) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin therapy is used to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Although large PDAs can manifest with symptoms of respiratory distress (due to heart failure), these symptoms are not seen immediately after birth. Furthermore, PDA would manifest with a characteristic machine-like, loud continuous murmur on auscultation. This newborn most likely has MAS, in which indomethacin is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin therapy is used in the treatment of early-onset neonatal pneumonia (i.e., within 6 days of birth), which manifests with features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, increased breathing effort, hypoxia) and asymmetrical, patchy infiltrates on chest x-ray, similar to what is seen here. Empiric antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin might also be indicated in newborns with MAS, as it is usually not possible to definitively rule out bacterial pneumonia. However, other steps in management (e.g., obtaining blood cultures) should be performed prior to initiating antibiotic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is used in the diagnosis of various infectious, inflammatory, and immunologic conditions. BAL is being investigated as a potential treatment for severe MAS but is not currently standard. A different step is more appropriate.

E) CORRECT:

The most appropriate step in the management of a newborn with MAS is to provide supportive care, which includes the administration of supplemental oxygen. Aspirated meconium in the tracheobronchial system leads to airway obstruction, chemical irritation, inflammation, and surfactant inactivation, culminating in alveolar collapse. Alveolar collapse results in areas of atelectasis and consequently a right-to-left pulmonary shunt, leading to areas of ventilation/perfusion mismatch with hypoxia and consequent hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. This can, in turn, lead to persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN). The administration of supplemental oxygen counters pulmonary vasoconstriction, helping to prevent or reverse PPHN. The management of severe cases should follow the standard steps of neonatal resuscitation.
questions.hint: Meconium-stained amniotic fluid and respiratory distress immediately after birth suggest meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS). Postterm delivery, oligohydramnios, and cesarean delivery are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text: Three days after birth, a female newborn has the onset of recurrent episodes of apnea. The episodes last 20–30 seconds and are accompanied by desaturation on pulse oximetry and bradycardia. She starts breathing again when the sole of her foot is tapped. She was delivered at 29 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman and weighed 1100 g (2 lb 7 oz). Apgar scores were 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The patient was taken to a tertiary-level neonatal intensive care unit immediately after delivery, where she has been monitored since in an incubator with free-flow oxygen. The newborn's skin appears pink. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 56/29 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination and a chest x-ray show no abnormalities. The results of a complete blood count and serum studies are within normal limits. Blood culture and lumbar puncture results are pending. In addition to nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

choices.text: No further treatment is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Few nonsevere episodes of AOP can be managed with supportive measures (e.g., maintaining a physiological neck position and appropriate incubator temperature, avoiding excessive nasal suctioning) as well as nasal CPAP to keep the upper airways open and improve oxygenation. This patient has had multiple episodes accompanied by desaturation and requires tactile stimulation to trigger spontaneous breathing. Therefore, additional therapy is indicated.

B) CORRECT:

AOP reflects immature respiratory control and is commonly seen in preterm neonates or neonates with very low birth weight, with the incidence inversely proportional to the gestational age. AOP typically manifests during the first few days after birth and is diagnosed clinically. Management includes supportive measures such as maintaining a physiological neck position, appropriate incubator temperature, and avoidance of excessive nasal suctioning. Other causes of apnea (e.g., sepsis) should also be ruled out. Additionally, nasal CPAP is indicated in all infants with AOP to keep the upper airways open and to improve oxygenation by improving the ventilation-perfusion ratio. Methylxanthines, such as caffeine, are the mainstay of pharmacological treatment and stimulate respiration, presumably by blocking adenosine receptors. Caffeine therapy is the preferred drug and is indicated in patients with recurrent episodes who require tactile stimulation (e.g., tapping the sole of the foot) to trigger spontaneous breathing, or if ventilatory support is necessary.

Given the high likelihood of developing AOP, caffeine can be administered prophylactically to neonates who are extremely preterm (< 28 weeks' gestation) or have an extremely low birth weight (< 1000 g).

C) INCORRECT:

Surfactant therapy is indicated in preterm neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) for whom an initial trial of nasal CPAP has been unsuccessful. Although premature neonates have a high risk of NRDS, this patient does not have features that suggest this condition, such as tachypnea, grunting, or nasal flaring. Furthermore, typical findings of NRDS include diffuse ground-glass densities and air bronchograms seen on chest x-ray as well as diminished breath sounds on auscultation. Surfactant therapy has no role in the treatment of AOP.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone) may be used in the treatment of severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), which can manifest with episodes of desaturation. However, this patient has no other features (e.g., tachypnea, grunting, nasal flaring) that suggest BPD. Moreover, abnormal chest x-ray findings (e.g., fine granular densities, areas of atelectasis interspersed with areas of hyperinflation) and abnormal lung auscultation (e.g., rales or decreased breath sounds) are expected in BPD.

E) INCORRECT:

Acid suppression therapy may be used with caution in the treatment of severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in neonates. All neonates have GERD to some extent because of transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. The gastric fluid stimulates the laryngeal chemoreflex response, which is overactive in preterm neonates, resulting in apnea. Although apnea and desaturation may be symptoms of GERD, poor weight gain and feeding intolerance are also expected findings.
questions.hint: Episodes of apnea that last > 20 seconds or that are accompanied by bradycardia and/or oxygen desaturation in an otherwise healthy premature neonate indicate apnea of prematurity (AOP). This condition occurs as a result of a combination of airflow obstruction at the nasopharyngeal level (obstructive apnea) and decreased respiratory drive (central apnea).

questions.text:
A 2-hour-old female infant, born at home as planned with a certified professional midwife present, is brought to the emergency department (ED) by ambulance with persistent cyanosis and tachypnea. She was born at 41 weeks’ gestation weighing 4000 grams.
The midwife notes that the pregnancy was remarkable for ruptured membranes with meconium-stained amniotic fluid 5 hours before delivery. The infant required stimulation and received blow-by oxygen at home until the emergency medical personnel arrived and started her on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for central cyanosis. Her Apgar score was 6 at one minute after birth and 7 at five minutes after birth.
Upon arrival in the ED, the infant has oxygen saturations of 80% measured in the left foot and 93% measured in the right hand, a respiratory rate of 90 breaths per minute, and a heart rate of 180 beats per minute. She is receiving CPAP at a pressure level of 6 cm of water and a fraction of inspired oxygen of 1.0. She is grunting and has intercostal retractions and coarse breath sounds. A 2/6 continuous systolic murmur is heard at the mid-to-upper left sternal border. Femoral pulses are 2+, but the capillary refill is 5 seconds.
A central venous catheter is placed and a chest radiograph is obtained (figure). Given the persistent hypoxemia and work of breathing, the infant is intubated and mechanically ventilated.
What is the most likely cause of hypoxemia in this patient?

choices.text: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation, history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, and evidence of shunting with a preductal oxygen saturation higher than postductal oxygen saturation are all consistent with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.

Pulmonary hypertension is a normal physiologic state for the fetus, because the placenta is the organ of oxygenation, and only 6% to 8% of circulating blood passes through the lungs. With the first breath, the lungs inflate and pulmonary vascular resistance typically begins to drop. However, when there is an abnormal circulatory transition from fetal to ex-utero life — for example, because of anatomic abnormalities (congenital diaphragmatic hernia, pulmonary hypoplasia), parenchymal lung disease (respiratory distress syndrome, meconium aspiration, pneumonia), neonatal sepsis, or vascular conditions (idiopathic pulmonary hypertension, alveolar capillary dysplasia) — pulmonary hypertension can persist.

In this patient, the clinically significant pulmonary hypertension is likely related to meconium aspiration, as there was evidence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Meconium-stained fluid is seen in about 15% of pregnancies, and in 5% of those pregnancies, the infant develops meconium aspiration syndrome, which is characterized by respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypertension. Meconium inactivates pulmonary surfactant, resulting in heterogeneous alveolar collapse, hyperexpansion from ball-valve effect, and alteration of the normal decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance after birth.

The hypoxemia due to pulmonary hypertension can range from mild (requiring only observation or nasal cannula) to severe (requiring nitric oxide, mechanical ventilation, or extracorporeal cardiopulmonary bypass). The ductus arteriosus functionally closes by 24 hours of age in virtually all healthy full-term neonates, but that closure may be delayed in children with congenital heart disease, prematurity, sepsis, and conditions that result in pulmonary hypertension. When this delay occurs, deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle passes through the pulmonic trunk to the relatively lower-resistance descending aorta via the patent ductus arteriosus, rather than through the relatively higher-resistance pulmonary arteries. As a result, the preductal oxygen saturation will be higher than the postductal saturation, as seen in this patient.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of hypoxemia in a full-term neonate whose preductal oxygen saturation is higher than postductal and whose history is consistent with meconium aspiration is persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn.

B) INCORRECT:

Dextro-transposition of the great arteries (D-TGA) results in reverse differential cyanosis, with the preductal oxygen saturation lower than the postductal saturation. In this condition, deoxygenated blood from the body returns to the right ventricle and then passes into the ascending aorta without traveling through the lungs for oxygenation. Some oxygenated blood, having passed through the left ventricle to the lungs, will traverse the patent ductus to mix with the deoxygenated blood in the descending aorta. The result is higher post ductal saturation. Neonates with D-TGA are cyanotic at birth, and chest radiograph findings may be unremarkable or may show hyperexpanded lung fields with a normal cardiac silhouette.

C) INCORRECT:

Isolated coarctation of the aorta manifests after ductus closure and results in diminished perfusion distal to the coarctation — diminished pulses in the lower extremities, differential blood pressures in the upper versus lower extremities, decreased urine output, and (if not recognized and treated) shock and death. This patient is newly born and likely to still have a patent ductus arteriosus. Although coarctation may manifest with split oxygen saturations before the ductus closes, the neonate would not be symptomatic until the ductus narrows enough to prevent distal blood flow and cause cardiac strain. Coarctation is also not associated with parenchymal lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is caused by inadequate production of pulmonary surfactant and is most commonly seen in premature infants, not full-term infants like this patient. Full-term infants of women with diabetes are also at risk of inadequate surfactant production. Chest radiographs in patients with respiratory distress syndrome typically show ground-glass infiltrates in a diffusely homogeneous pattern. Secondary surfactant deficiency or inactivation may occur with aspiration syndromes (e.g., from meconium or drowning).

E) INCORRECT:

Isolated ventricular septal defects are not symptomatic until pulmonary vascular resistance drops and permits left-to-right shunting across the lesion, resulting in signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure, generally at several weeks to months of life. In patients with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn, the pulmonary pressures are elevated, thus preventing left-to-right flow of blood through the ventricular septal defect. Patients with a ventricular septal defect present with normal oxygen saturation levels.

questions.text:
A male infant is born at 33 weeks’ gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 26-year-old primiparous mother in the setting of premature rupture of membranes with preterm labor. The pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated, and prenatal laboratory results were normal. Maternal group B streptococcus status is unknown at delivery. The infant emerges vigorous with good tone and is brought to the warmer, where he undergoes routine resuscitation per Neonatal Resuscitation Program guidelines and is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit.
At 30 minutes of life, the infant develops tachypnea, subcostal retractions, and grunting. He is started on continuous positive airway pressure for respiratory support. However, he demonstrates worsening respiratory distress, with increased work of breathing and an increasing oxygen requirement to maintain oxygen saturations.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
In addition to starting antibiotics, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although preterm neonates are at risk for apnea of prematurity resulting from immature respiratory control, this infant is not demonstrating periods of apnea or periodic breathing with desaturation events that would be an indication for the initiation of caffeine.

B) CORRECT:

This infant has respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), a condition caused by surfactant deficiency in the preterm lungs. Surfactant is a compound that the lungs begin to secrete around the 20th week of gestation to reduce alveolar surface tension and thereby prevent alveolar collapse. Before approximately 35 weeks’ gestation, the amount and quality of pulmonary surfactant may be inadequate to prevent alveolar collapse after birth. The characteristic ground-glass appearance on chest radiograph is classic for the disease and is caused by microatelectasis.

Treatments for RDS include continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and, if there is no response to CPAP, administration of surfactant based on institutional guidelines. The risk of infection is a possibility in any neonate with respiratory distress; thus, the addition of antibiotics should also be considered.

Key learning point: Treatment of respiratory distress syndrome in a neonate includes administration of surfactant.
Image Description:

Surfactant reduces alveolar surface tension. In surfactant deficiency, increased surface tension results in increased alveolar collapse during expiration and decreased alveolar expansion during inspiration.

C) INCORRECT:

Although lung edema may complicate RDS, there are not sufficient published data to support the routine use of loop diuretics in the management of RDS, especially before first-line treatment with surfactant.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient is experiencing alveolar collapse related to surfactant deficiency. Until exogenous surfactant is administered, this patient will require positive airway pressure to keep the alveoli open. Although high-flow nasal cannula can provide some degree of positive end-expiratory pressure, switching this infant in distress to high-flow nasal cannula would not provide any additional respiratory support.

E) INCORRECT:

Needle decompression is the treatment for pneumothorax, a disorder of air leakage into the pleural space that can occur in preterm infants who have surfactant deficiency or who have received positive pressure ventilation. Chest radiograph findings most commonly show unilateral absence of lung markings and increased radiolucency in the peripheral lung field. This patient’s radiograph does not show findings consistent with a pneumothorax.

questions.text: Three hours after delivery, a 1800-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old primigravid woman. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 69/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows nasal flaring and expiratory grunting. A chest x-ray study shows diffuse ground-glass opacities and air bronchograms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) due to surfactant deficiency. NRDS is most common in premature infants because adequate surfactant concentration is not reached until 34 weeks' gestation. Without sufficient surfactant, increased surface tension of alveolar air sacs leads to their collapse, resulting in atelectasis, and decreased lung compliance. NRDS manifests up to 72 hours after birth with signs and symptoms of acute respiratory distress such as tachypnea (i.e., respiratory rate > 60/min), cyanosis, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds. Treatment primarily consists of noninvasive ventilation via nasal continuous positive airway pressure. If ventilation alone is unsuccessful, artificial surfactant can be administered endotracheally (see “Overview of NDRDS and its differential diagnoses” table).

As the lungs mature, lecithin levels, the major component of surfactant, increases. Therefore, amniotic fluid lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio can be used to assess for lung maturity, since sphingomyelin remains relatively constant. A ratio > 2 indicates adequate levels of surfactant.
Image Description:

Surfactant reduces alveolar surface tension. In surfactant deficiency, increased surface tension results in increased alveolar collapse during expiration and decreased alveolar expansion during inspiration.

B) INCORRECT:

Persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) can also lead to respiratory distress. With high pulmonary pressures, right-to-left shunting through fetal circulatory pathways (e.g., ductus arteriosus, foramen ovale) results in deoxygenated blood entering systemic circulation, causing hypoxia and cyanosis. Since the lung parenchyma is normal in PPHN, the chest x-ray would show clear lungs with decreased pulmonary vasculature due to shunting.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased lung vascular permeability (secondary to damage to the alveolar-capillary interface) can cause acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in adults. This newborn's respiratory distress is due to another underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of meconium during delivery can also lead to respiratory distress. However, meconium aspiration syndrome usually occurs in term or post-term neonates (because meconium usually first develops after 34 weeks' gestation) who have evidence of meconium in the amniotic fluid. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show patchy infiltrates, and hyperinflation secondary to air trapping from sticky meconium.

E) INCORRECT:

Delayed reabsorption of lung fluid can result in transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN), which also causes respiratory distress. However, TTN occurs most commonly in newborns > 35 weeks' gestation who are delivered by cesarean section without labor. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show hyperinflation, perihilar streaking, and fluid in the fissures.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features and x-ray findings suggest neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS).

questions.text: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 1780-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 30 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF), pulse rate is 140/min, respirations are 64/min, and blood pressure is 61/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows pale extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transient tachypnea of the newborn can also manifest with respiratory distress shortly after birth. However, this condition most commonly occurs in term neonates delivered by cesarean section, not preterm infants born by vaginal delivery. Furthermore, diffuse crackles rather than decreased breath sounds are typically heard on lung auscultation due to pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is caused by immature respiratory control and is commonly seen in preterm neonates or neonates with very low birth weight. While this patient's prematurity puts him at increased risk of developing AOP, the condition characteristically manifests with episodes of breathing pauses (usually > 20 seconds) that are frequently accompanied by hypoxemia and/or bradycardia. This patient has no evidence of prolonged apnea and his pulmonary findings are suggestive of a lung pathology rather than a lack of respiratory drive.

C) CORRECT:

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) affects approx. 10% of preterm infants and typically manifests with tachypnea (i.e., respiratory rate > 60/min), low O2 saturation, cyanosis, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, subcostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds. A chest x-ray showing diffuse, ground-glass densities with atelectasis confirms the diagnosis. Treatment of NRDS primarily involves emergent resuscitative measures, including nasal continuous positive airway pressure and stabilizing blood sugar levels and electrolytes.

See “Overview of NRDS and its differential diagnoses” table.

Key learning point: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is a common cause of respiratory distress in preterm infants due to surfactant deficiency, presenting with tachypnea, hypoxemia, grunting, retractions, and decreased breath sounds shortly after birth.

D) INCORRECT:

Meconium aspiration syndrome can also manifest with respiratory distress. However, this condition most commonly affects term or postterm neonates. Furthermore, there is usually some evidence of meconium in the amniotic fluid.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) can manifest with signs of respiratory distress. However, BPD is a chronic lung condition that develops in preterm infants who are exposed to prolonged (>28 days) mechanical ventilation and O2 therapy. Although this patient will be put at risk for BPD if he receives mechanical ventilation, he has no features of this condition at the moment.
questions.hint: This newborn's respiratory distress is most likely due to surfactant deficiency.

questions.text: A 770-g (1-lb 11-oz) female newborn delivered at 28 weeks' gestation develops rapid breathing, grunting, cyanosis, and subcostal retractions shortly after birth. Her mother did not receive any prenatal care. Breath sounds are decreased over both lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse fine, reticular densities bilaterally. Antenatal administration of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this infant's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endogenous epinephrine and other catecholamines are involved in promoting fetal lung maturity in-utero. However, epinephrine administration is not effective for the prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Maternal antenatal administration of betamethasone most likely would have prevented neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) in this patient. Glucocorticoids such as betamethasone and dexamethasone promote fetal lung maturity and increase the production of surfactant via stimulation of type II pneumocyte. Glucocorticoids are typically administered at least 48 hours before delivery in patients at risk of preterm birth, to ensure enough time for effect.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infant

The lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.

In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin is administered primarily to induce labor. While it can slightly increase fetal surfactant levels, oxytocin is not regularly used to promote fetal lung maturity and would not have prevented NRDS in this infant.

D) INCORRECT:

Physiological concentrations of insulin increase glucose uptake by type II pneumocyte and contribute to lung maturity. However, hyperinsulinemia has the opposite effect and delays lung maturity. Consequently, insulin is not used to prevent neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin is used therapeutically to close the ductus arteriosus in patients born with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Indomethacin is not indicated in the prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical signs (tachypnea, grunting, subcostal retractions, cyanosis, and decreased breath sounds), imaging findings of diffuse fine, reticular (ground-glass) densities, and history of premature birth without prenatal care make neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) the most likely diagnosis.
